facts.text: Writ Petition No. 145 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 145 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 8, 1963 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 8. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-The first petitioner is a private limited Company

facts.text: First petitioner is a private limited company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, 1913; second petitioner is a director of the company.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner is a private limited Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 and the second petitioner is a Director of the Company. The Company maintains 23 establishments

facts.text: Company maintains 23 establishments for manufacturing bidis in Districts of Nasik, Poona and Ahmednagar in Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The Company maintains 23 establishments for manufacturing bidis in the District of Nasik, Poona and Ahmednagar in the State of Maharashtra. A large majority of these establishments

facts.text: Large majority of establishments borne on register of factories maintained by Chief Inspector under Factories Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: A large majority of these establishments are borne on the registar of factories maintained by the Chief Inspector of Factories under the Factories Act, 63 of 1948. Craftsmen called rollers

facts.text: Rollers prepare bidis using materials supplied by company; establishments open specified hours but rollers not bound to fixed period, come and leave conveniently, paid per bidi by fixed tariff.

anchor.surface_text: Craftsmen called rollers, attend these establishments and prepare bidis, using materials supplied by the Company. The establishments remain open during specified hours but the rollers are number bound to attend for any fixed period a roller may companye to and leave the establishment according as is companyvenient to him, and he is paid for the bidis turned out by him according to a fixed tariff.

facts.text: This is accepted modus operandi in bidi establishments in Maharashtra region.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this is the accepted modus of work in bidi establishments in the Maharashtra region. These establishments were, it was held by the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Bombay High Court held these establishments are factories and rollers are workers under Factories Act, 1948 (State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli).

anchor.surface_text: These establishments were, it was held by the Bombay High Court, factories and the rollers work- ing therein were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act 63 of 1948 The State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli  1 . In that case the High Court held that the expression employed in s. 2  1  of the Factories Act

facts.text: Supreme Court in Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra held bidi rollers not employed within s.2(1) Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: But this Court in Shankar Balaji Waje v. The State of Maharashtra  2  --  Subba Rao, J. dissenting - held in dealing with the case of workers in an establishment for manufacturing bidis whose attendance was characterised by the features hereinafter set out, that they were number employed within the meaning of s. 2  1 ,

facts.text: Features noted by SC: no contract of service, no fixed hours, free to come/leave, no supervision, paid per quantity, materials supplied but can take home, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The features numbericed by the Court were, that there was numberagreement or companytract of service between the owner of the establishment and the bidi roller the bidi roller was number bound to attend the factory for any fixed hours or to work for any fixed period he was free to go to the factory at any time he liked and was equally free to leave the factory whenever he liked the bidi roller companyld be absent from work on any day, and if his absence was expected to be of a duration longer than ten days he informed the owner number because he had to obtain

facts.text: After SC judgment, owners denied weekly holidays, wages in lieu, and access to Factories Act inspectors.

anchor.surface_text: Since this Judgment was pronounced, owners of bidi-making Establishments in the State of Maharashtra companymenced denying to the bidi rollers benefit of weekly holidays and wages in lieu of holidays previously accorded to them and even denied access to the Inspectors appointed under the Factories Act to their establishments.

facts.text: More than 35,000 bidi rollers on pay rolls of establishments on Chief Inspector's register in Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: There are in the State of Maharashtra more than 35000 bidi rollers borne on the pay rolls of bidi-making establishments on the register maintained by the Chief Inspector of Factories.

facts.text: Many other bidi establishments not on the register.

anchor.surface_text: There are also many other bidi making establishments which are number so borne on the register of the Chief Inspector.

facts.text: Grave unrest among bidi rollers due to denial of previous benefits.

anchor.surface_text: There was grave unrest among the bidi rollers resulting from the denial of benefits previously enjoyed by them.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra issued notification under s.85 Factories Act declaring provisions apply to specified places including many of company's establishments.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to protect the bidi rollers against exploitation by the owners of bidi making establishments and against deprivation of the benefits enjoyed by them, the Government of Maharashtra issued the following Notification in exercise of the powers vested under s. 85 of the Factories Act - In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 85 of the Factories Act, 1948  LXIII of 1948 , the Government of Maharashtra hereby declares that all the provisions of the said Act shall apply to the places specified in companyumn 2 of the Schedule appended hereto ... To the numberification was appended a Schedule  including many of the establishments of the Company

facts.text: Effect of notification: bidi rollers in scheduled places deemed workers entitled to Factories Act benefits.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the Notification was to make bidi rollers in places set out in the Schedule deemed workers, and oil that account entitled to the benefits provided to workers under the Factories Act.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge validity of s.85 Factories Act and notification on grounds of infringing Arts.14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then challenged by this petition the validity of s. 85 of the Factories Act and the Notification issued in exercise of the authority companyferred thereby, oil the plea that the provisions of the section and the Notification issued thereunder infringe the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Arts. 14 and 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bombay High Court and other High Courts held bidi workers entitled to Factories Act benefits before SC decision.

anchor.surface_text: Before, the impugned Notification was issued, the Bombay and other High Courts had held that bidi workers who though number servants of the owners of the bidi factories in which they were working, were still employed in a manufacturing process to whom the benefits of the Factories Act were admissible.

facts.text: Affidavit of Mr. V.N. Pimenta explains basis for selecting factories on Chief Inspector's register.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, however, the affidavit of Mr. V. N. Pimenta, Under Secretary to Government of Maharashtra in the Industries and Labour Department, discloses clearly the basis on which the factories mentioned in the Schedule were selected by the Notification under s. 85 1 .

facts.text: Notification issued to maintain industrial peace and protect bidi rollers post-SC judgment.

anchor.surface_text: On careful companysideration of the facts of this  Shankar Balaji Wajes  case the Government of Maharashtra was of the view that for the purpose of. protecting the bidi rollers against any arbitrary treatment by the bidi manufacturers, and to maintain the protection given to them under the Factories Act ... He further stated that the impugned Notification was issued to maintain industrial peace and harmony.

facts.text: Government enquiring about other factories not on register for possible inclusion.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pimenta said that the Government was making enquiries about such other factories and that they would or would number be brought under the purview of the Act, as circumstances demanded, by amendment of the impugned numberification under s. 85 of the Factories Act when the enquiries were over.
Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.
Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Section 85 of the Factories Act imposes unreasonable restrictions upon the fundamental right of the owner to carry on his business under Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: Section 85, it is contended, is invalid on the grounds that it imposes unreasonable restrictions upon the fundamental right of the owner to carry on his business, and it enables

issues.text: Whether Section 85 of the Factories Act enables the State Government by notification to arbitrarily discriminate between owners of establishments who are similarly situated, violating Article 14?

anchor.surface_text: the State Government by a Notification arbitrarily to discriminate between owners of establishments who are similarly situate, inasmuch as the Act confers an unguided and uncontrolled power to select places to be deemed factories by a Notification under s. 85

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification issued under Section 85 arbitrarily selects some bidi manufacturing establishments for application of the Factories Act, violating Article 14?
Whether extending provisions like Sections 79 and 80 of the Factories Act to deemed workers under Section 85 imposes unreasonable restrictions under Article 19(1)(g)?

arguments.claim: Section 85 is invalid as it imposes unreasonable restrictions upon the fundamental right of the owner to carry on his business under Article 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Section 85, it is contended, is invalid on the grounds that it imposes unreasonable restrictions upon the fundamental right of the owner to carry on his business, and it enables

arguments.court_reasoning: Imposition of restrictions reasonable in modern industrial relations context; serves purpose of protecting workers' health and safety; extension to deemed workers effectuates Act's object

arguments.claim: Section 85 enables the State Government by notification to arbitrarily discriminate between owners of similarly situated establishments violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: the State Government by a Notification arbitrarily to discriminate between owners of establishments who are similarly situate, inasmuch as the Act confers an unguided and uncontrolled power to select places to be deemed factories by a Notification under s. 85

arguments.court_reasoning: Power guided by policy to protect workers; reasonable classification based on circumstances, industry, locality; follows doctrine of reasonable classification under Art.14

arguments.claim: The impugned notification arbitrarily selects some bidi establishments violating Article 14
arguments.court_reasoning: Selection based on register of Chief Inspector rational in emergency post-SC judgment; temporary exclusion of others pending enquiry; maintains industrial peace

arguments.claim: Application of provisions like ss.79 and 80 to deemed workers who are not under contract of service and not bound by fixed hours imposes unreasonable restrictions under Art.19(1)(g)
arguments.court_reasoning: Ss.79,80 apply only if deemed workers fulfill full working hours (ss.61,71,66) for 240 days; same as regular workers; no unreasonable restriction

arguments.claim: Section 85 enacted to confer authority on State Govt to extend Act's provisions to places/persons not otherwise factories/workers to provide benefits

anchor.surface_text: The section is enacted with the object of conferring authority to extend in appropriate cases the provisions of the Act to establishments which are otherwise not factories within the meaning of the Act, and to ensure to persons working in factories even if not workers within the meaning of the Act., the benefits provided thereby.

arguments.claim: Restrictions under Factories Act, including extensions via s.85, are reasonable under Art.19(1)(g) as they protect workers from exploitation and ensure health/safety
arguments.court_reasoning: Modern recognition of State's concern in preventing labour exploitation; effectuates Act's protective object

arguments.claim: Power under s.85 is not arbitrary but guided by circumstances of industry/locality to secure workers' protection; reasonable classification under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but not reasonable classification for the purpose of legislation. ... The power to extend the regulatory provisions of the Act is therefore not intended to confer an arbitrary power to pick and choose between establishments similarly situate it is granted with a view to secure the protection of persons engaged in industrial occupations in the light of special circumstances of a particular industry, a locality or an establishment, where circumstances justifying the extension of the protection exist.

arguments.court_reasoning: Follows Bhikusa Yamasa; policy on face of Act; authority has means for enquiry

arguments.court_reasoning: Justifies s.85 as response to documented exploitation in bidi sector

holdings.text: Section 85 of the Factories Act does not impose unreasonable restrictions on the fundamental right to carry on business under Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: But imposition of such restrictions is not and cannot be regarded, in the context of the modem outlook on industrial relations, as unreasonable. Extension of the benefits of the Factories Act to premises and workers not falling strictly within the purview of the Act, is intended to serve the same purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions protect workers' health and safety in modern industrial context; extension via s.85 effectuates Act's protective object without unreasonableness.

holdings.text: Section 85 does not enable arbitrary discrimination violating Article 14; power is guided by policy to protect workers in special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but not reasonable classification for the purpose of legislation. ... The power to extend the regulatory provisions of the Act is therefore not intended to confer an arbitrary power to pick and choose between establishments similarly situate it is granted with a view to secure the protection of persons engaged in industrial occupations in the light of special circumstances of a particular industry, a locality or an establishment, where circumstances justifying the extension of the protection exist.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows reasonable classification doctrine; power guided by Act's object, local conditions, and authority's enquiry capacity; cites Bhikusa Yamasa precedent.

holdings.text: The impugned notification under s.85 is valid and does not arbitrarily discriminate under Article 14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Selection of registered factories rational post-Shankar Balaji unrest; temporary pending enquiries; maintains industrial peace; objective basis.

holdings.text: Extending ss.79 and 80 via s.85 to deemed workers does not impose unreasonable restrictions under Article 19(1)(g).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Benefits apply only if deemed workers fulfill full factory hours (ss.61,71,66) for 240 days, same as regular workers; consistent with Act's scheme and precedents like Bridhichand.

holdings.text: Section 85 authorizes State Government to deem certain places as factories and persons as workers to extend Act's protections notwithstanding definitional limits.

anchor.surface_text: The section is enacted with the object of conferring authority to extend in appropriate cases the provisions of the Act to establishments which are otherwise not factories within the meaning of the Act, and to ensure to persons working in factories even if not workers within the meaning of the Act., the benefits provided thereby.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation based on text, history of factory legislation, and bidi industry conditions documented in reports.

holdings.text: Shankar Balaji holding distinguished as no s.85 notification applied there; s.85 overrides s.2(l) 'employed' and s.2(m) definitions.

anchor.surface_text: But this Court in Shankar Balaji Waje v. The State of Maharashtra  2  ... held ... that they were not employed within the meaning of s. 2(1), ... Since this Judgment was pronounced, owners ... commenced denying ... benefits

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.85 expressly deems notwithstanding lack of employment contract or minimum numbers; notification effectuates override.

precedents.citation: The State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli  1

anchor.surface_text: The State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli  1 . In that case the High Court held that the expression employed in s. 2  1  of the Factories Act, 1948 does number necessarily involve the relationship of master and servant, and therefore owners of bidi establishments had to companyform to the requirements of the Factories Act and to afford to the workers the benefits provided under that Act, even though the workers did number maintain uniform hours of attendance, and were paid only for bidis turned out by them.

precedents.case_name: The State v. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli
precedents.cited_proposition: expression employed in s. 2(1) of the Factories Act, 1948 does not necessarily involve the relationship of master and servant; owners of bidi establishments had to conform to the requirements of the Factories Act even though workers did not maintain uniform hours of attendance and were paid piece-rate

precedents.citation: Shankar Balaji Waje v. The State of Maharashtra  2

anchor.surface_text: Shankar Balaji Waje v. The State of Maharashtra  2  --  Subba Rao, J. dissenting - held in dealing with the case of workers in an establishment for manufacturing bidis whose attendance was characterised by the features hereinafter set out, that they were number employed within the meaning of s. 2  1 , and companyld number claim the privileges accorded to workers by ss. 79 and 80 of that Act.

precedents.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: bidi rollers not employed within meaning of s. 2(1) Factories Act due to absence of contract of service, no fixed hours, no supervision, piece-rate payment; not entitled to privileges under ss. 79 and 80
precedents.cited_holding: bidi roller could not be said to be employed by the owner and was not therefore a worker, there being no contract of employment

anchor.surface_text: State V. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli  1  and Ram Chandra Prasad v. The State of Bihar  2 . The Factories Act, as the preamble recites is an Act to companysolidate and amend the law regulating labour in factories.

precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'employed' in s. 2(1) Factories Act includes mere engagement or occupation in manufacturing process without master-servant relation

precedents.citation: Ram Chandra Prasad v. The State of Bihar  2

anchor.surface_text: State V. Alisaheb Kashim Tamboli  1  and Ram Chandra Prasad v. The State of Bihar  2 . The Factories Act, as the preamble recites is an Act to companysolidate and amend the law regulating labour in factories. The Act is enacted primarily with the object of protecting workers employed in factories against industrial and occupational hazards.

precedents.case_name: Ram Chandra Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'employed' in s. 2(1) Factories Act includes mere engagement without master-servant relation

precedents.citation: M S. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union  1

anchor.surface_text: M S. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union  1 , in dealing with the validity of certain provisions of the Minimum Wages Act, it was observed by this Court The object and policy of the Legislature appear on the face of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya v. Sangamner Akola Taluka Bidi Kamgar Union
precedents.cited_proposition: selective application of law by appropriate government based on local conditions and policy to prevent exploitation constitutes reasonable classification under Art. 14; entrusting authority to government with guidance does not infringe Art. 14

precedents.citation: Bridhichand Sharma v. First, Civil Judge, Nagpur  1

anchor.surface_text: Bridhichand Sharma v. First, Civil Judge, Nagpur  1 , this Court in dealing with the question whether rollers in a bidi factory who were obliged to work within the factory hours, but number for the entire period were entitled to the benefit of s. 79, held on a companysideration of all the circumstances, that the bidi rollers being employed in the factory were workers within the meaning of s. 2  1  of the Factories Act, and entitled to that benefit.

precedents.case_name: Bridhichand Sharma v. First Civil Judge Nagpur
precedents.cited_proposition: bidi rollers employed in factory entitled to benefit of s. 79 if they fulfill minimum number of working days; attendance for full period fixed by factory owner required to qualify
precedents.cited_holding: workers entitled to leave under s. 79 if attended minimum working days for appropriate full period

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Honble Court in the case of Shankar Balaji Waje a Notification under s. 85 of the Factories Act, 1948 should be issued. Accordingly, the Government of Maharashtra issued the impugned Notification including therein those factories which were on the register of Factories main- tained by the Chief Inspector of Factories.

precedents.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: bidi rollers not workers under Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in Shankar Balagi Wajes case  1 , there was grave unrest among bidi rollers and the State Government felt obliged to intervene for the protection of bidi rollers against deprivation of benefits previously accorded to them

precedents.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: clarification that bidi workers not employed hence not entitled to Factories Act benefits

anchor.surface_text: The observations made in Shankar Balaji Wajes case  1 , that Pandurang was number bound to work for the period of work displayed in the factory and therefore his days of work for the purpose of s. 79 companyld number be calculated is number inconsistent with the view expressed by us.

precedents.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: worker not bound to fixed hours not entitled to count days for s. 79

precedents.case_name: Shankar Balaji Waje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: no notification under s.85; workers not deemed workers

justification_sets.label: Reasonable Classification (Article 14 Twin Test) support defeaters

anchor.surface_text: To companylude in our judgment s. 85 which authorises the State Government to issue a Notification applying all or any of the provisions of the Act to any place in which a manufacturing process is carried on, and which involves the companysequence that the place is deemed a factory and the persons working therein are deemed workers is number by itself discriminatory so as to infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution number does the provision amount to authorising imposition of unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the owner of the factory to carry on his business. The impugned Notification issued under s. 85 1  is also number open to attack on the ground that the State has issued the Notification by selecting for application of the provisions of the Act, some out of the places in which bidi manufacturing processes are carried on.

outcome.relief_summary: Validity of Section 85 of the Factories Act and the Maharashtra Government notification upheld; challenge under Articles 14 and 19(1)(g) rejected

anchor.surface_text: But imposition of such restrictions is not and cannot be regarded, in the context of the modem outlook on industrial relations, as unreasonable. Extension of the benefits of the Factories Act to premises and workers not falling strictly within the purview of the Act, is intended to serve the same purpose.

To companylude in our judgment s. 85 which authorises the State Government to issue a Notification applying all or any of the provisions of the Act to any place in which a manufacturing process is carried on, and which involves the companysequence that the place is deemed a factory and the persons working therein are deemed workers is number by itself discriminatory so as to infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution number does the provision amount to authorising imposition of unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the owner of the factory to carry on his business. The impugned Notification issued under s. 85 1  is also number open to attack on the ground that the State has issued the Notification by selecting for application of the provisions of the Act, some out of the places in which bidi manufacturing processes are carried on.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but not reasonable classification for the purpose of legislation. ... The power to extend the regulatory provisions of the Act is therefore not intended to confer an arbitrary power to pick and choose between establishments similarly situate it is granted with a view to secure the protection of persons engaged in industrial occupations in the light of special circumstances of a particular industry, a locality or an establishment, where circumstances justifying the extension of the protection exist.

To companylude in our judgment s. 85 which authorises the State Government to issue a Notification applying all or any of the provisions of the Act to any place in which a manufacturing process is carried on, and which involves the companysequence that the place is deemed a factory and the persons working therein are deemed workers is number by itself discriminatory so as to infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution number does the provision amount to authorising imposition of unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of the owner of the factory to carry on his business. The impugned Notification issued under s. 85 1  is also number open to attack on the ground that the State has issued the Notification by selecting for application of the provisions of the Act, some out of the places in which bidi manufacturing processes are carried on.
